question: What do I do if I think someone's breached client confidentiality?
context: Data Breach Response Plan V01_2305 TBC Responsibilities and delegations Record of procedure development Version Date of Approved Date for Review This procedure applies to Specific responsibilities Procedure approval All staff with access to personal information CEO, IT Committee IT Committee Data breach response plan Policy Hope Holistic Care is committed to protecting the privacy and personal information that it holds about individuals. Hope Holistic Care will act appropriately and in a timely manner in the event of a data breach, to contain the possible resulting harm and notify individuals affected as required. Definitions Data Breach: When personal information held by an organisation is disclosed accidentally, lost, or accessed without permission. This can be as a result of human error, or through malicious action by an employee or an external party. Examples include where a secure IT system containing personal information has been hacked, a storage device being lost by an employee, or an employee accidentally releasing personal information to the wrong person. Personal information: ‘Information about an identified individual, or an individual who is reasonably identifiable: whether the information or opinion is true or not; and whether the information or opinion is recorded in a material form or not.’ (Privacy Act 1988, Section 6) Procedure Identify When staff have reason to believe there has been a data breach, they should inform the Office immediately. At this time, details such as when and how the breach was discovered, and by whom, should be recorded. This will be recorded in the incident register. Contain As soon as a breach or suspected breach has been identified, any steps to contain or limit the potential harm should be taken. This may include shutting down a system that has been breached, or recovering any records. The CEO will complete a preliminary assessment of the breach and take any immediate action to contain the breach if possible. Assess If the preliminary assessment finds that further investigation and assessment is necessary to understand the nature and extent of the breach, it will be escalated to the data breach response team. The team will work together to gather information, assess risks and the likelihood of serious harm from the breach, and therefore whether it is an ‘eligible’ (notifiable) breach. To evaluate whether a known data breach is notifiable, consider the following three questions: • Has there been unauthorised access, unauthorised disclosure, accidental loss, or theft of personal information that the organisation holds? Data Breach Response Plan _POL_V01_2305 1|Page Data breach response plan For example, the organisation’s database is hacked, a portable storage device containing personal information is lost, or the organisation accidentally releases personal information to the wrong person. • Is it likely that this may result in serious harm to individual/s whose data has been breached? This can include but is not limited to psychological, financial, emotional, physical or reputational harm. To be able to accurately assess the likelihood and seriousness of harm, it requires looking at the context of the data and how it may have been breached. For information about the factors to consider when deciding whether harm is likely and/or serious, refer to section 26WG of the Privacy Amendment (Notifiable Data Breaches) Act 2017 • Does the likelihood of serious harm remain despite taking available remedial action? The obligation to notify the OAIC can be avoided if the organisation takes remedial action in a timely manner to prevent the risk of harm occurring, either by making the harm unlikely to occur, or non-serious. If the answer to the above three questions is yes, then the breach classifies as an eligible data breach and organisations are required to notify the OAIC and any affected individuals. If there are reasonable grounds to suspect that there has been a data breach, the data response team should conduct an assessment of the suspected breach. The assessment of a suspected breach must take place within 30 days of it occurring, and should seek to find out the likelihood of serious harm occurring as a result of the suspected breach. If it is assessed to be likely, this has the same notification obligations as a known data breach under the NDB Scheme. Take remedial action Remedial action can be taken at any point throughout the data breach response process – the sooner the better. However, it may be that the full extent and nature of the breach, and therefore the actions that could be taken, are not known until after assessing and investigating the breach. Examples of remedial action include remotely deleting sensitive information from a laptop which has been lost, or emailing affected individuals with advice to change their password details for an online account for which login information may have been hacked. The data breach response team should document the process of any remedial action, making sure to document rationale and reasoning as to why a certain conclusion has been made. If, after the remedial action has been taken, the risk of harm is reduced so that it is unlikely to occur, or non-serious, then there is no requirement to notify. Even if there is no requirement, however, the data response team should consider whether to contact affected individuals with advice for further protecting their information as a customer service measure. Notify Once a breach has been assessed as eligible, relevant individuals and bodies should be notified as soon as practicable. Notification must include the following information as a minimum: Data Breach Response Plan _POL_V01_2305 2|Page Data breach response plan • The organisation’s name and contact details • Description of the data breach • Type of information involved in the breach • Advice and recommendations for individuals to take in response 1. The OAIC The CEO is responsible for notifying and liaising with the OAIC for data breaches which have been assessed as eligible for the purposes of the Notifiable Data Breaches Scheme, using the OAIC’s Notifiable Data Breach form. 2. Notification of individuals who are at likely risk of serious harm due to the data breach The way notification occurs will depend on the context and nature of the breach, and the relationship of the individuals affected to the organisation. It should occur as soon as practicable after completing the notification statement for the OAIC. Individuals may be contacted by phone and email. A public notification may also occur. Notification to affected individuals may contain an explanation of what happened to their personal information, an apology, description of what measures have been put in place as a result of the breach, and advice on what they can do to further protect their information. Record and review Data breach log A data breach log will record all instances of data breaches or suspected breaches, as well as document assessments of the breach and any changes made as a result of a breach. All staff should be made aware of the log, and the CEO will be responsible for ensuring that all breaches or suspected breaches are recorded accurately in the log. Review Whether or not the breach or suspected breach was notifiable, a review should be conducted into processes relating to the breach to strengthen protections in the future. Depending on the type and seriousness of the breach, this may include: • A full investigation into how the breach occurred • Implement measures to ensure it does not reoccur, documented in a prevention plan • Reviews of security, cybersecurity and ICT policies and procedures • Audit of implementation of relevant policies and procedures • Additional staff training about privacy and data breach responses Data Breach Response Plan _POL_V01_2305 3|Page
response: If you suspect that someone has breached client confidentiality at Hope Holistic Care, it's important to act promptly and follow these steps: Report the Concern: As soon as you become aware of the possible breach, report the incident to your supervisor or manager. If the suspected breach involves your manager, or if you feel it's not appropriate to report to them, you should escalate the matter to the next level of management or directly to the Chief Executive Officer (CEO). Document the Incident: Take notes of what you observed, including dates, times, and the nature of the potential breach. This information may be necessary for the subsequent investigation. Data Breach Response Plan: Hope Holistic Care has a Data Breach Response Plan that is meant to be activated in the event of a breach. The plan includes the assessment of the situation, containment of the breach, and evaluation of the risks associated with the breach. Follow this plan and work with the designated team or personnel tasked with managing data breaches. Maintain Confidentiality: It is important to maintain the confidentiality of all information related to the breach during the investigation process. Only discuss the breach with those who are directly involved in handling it, such as your supervisor, the appointed investigator, or the CEO. Cooperate with the Investigation: If an investigation is undertaken, provide any information you have and cooperate fully with the investigators. Remember, confidentiality is a cornerstone of care services, and any breach could have serious repercussions for clients and the organization. The policies at Hope Holistic Care are designed to protect client information and upholding these standards is everyone's responsibility. If you require further assistance regarding the specific procedures to follow, you should consult the organization's policy documentation or speak with the appropriate person in your organization.

response: To prevent data breaches at Hope Holistic Care, it is important to follow good practices and procedures to secure personal and sensitive information. Here are some proactive steps to take: Education and Training: Educate all staff on the importance of data security and their specific responsibilities. This should include training on the acceptable use of personal devices, recognizing phishing attempts, and safe handling of sensitive information . Device Protocols: Ensure that any personal devices used for work are compliant with organizational protocols. This includes having up-to-date anti-virus software, strong passwords, and secure configurations . Limit Use of Personal Devices: Restrict the use of personal devices for work purposes to certain employees, based on the compatibility of technology and security considerations . Avoid Using Unauthorized Cloud Services: Employees should not use cloud-based apps or backup services that are not approved by the organization, as they may transfer sensitive data to unsecured parties . Preventative Technology: Implement technical measures like firewalls, encryption, and intrusion detection systems to protect against unauthorized access to your network and data. Regular Audits and Monitoring: Conduct regular audits of IT systems and monitor data access logs to detect unauthorized activities and ensure all policies are being followed【3†policy.json†Data Breach Response Plan】. Restrict Data Access: Limit access to sensitive information to only those employees who need it to perform their job functions. Secure Physical Access: Secure physical access to buildings and storage areas where sensitive information might be kept. Incident Response Plan: Have a clear data breach response plan in place so that employees know exactly what to do if they suspect a breach【0†policy.json†Data Breach Response Plan】. By incorporating these preventative measures, Hope Holistic Care can greatly reduce the risk of data breaches, protect sensitive information, and maintain trust with clients and stakeholders.

response: The criteria for determining if a data breach needs to be reported under the Data Breach Response Plan [Data_Breach_Response_Plan_POL_V01_2305] include the following: Unauthorised Actions: Has there been unauthorised access, unauthorised disclosure, accidental loss, or theft of personal information that the organization holds? For example, a system hack, loss of a storage device containing personal information, or accidental release of information to the wrong individual. Risk of Serious Harm: Is it likely this may result in serious harm to individuals whose data has been breached? Serious harm can include psychological, financial, emotional, physical, or reputational damage. The context of the data and how it may have been breached are important for accurately assessing the likelihood and seriousness of harm. Effectiveness of Remedial Action: Does the likelihood of serious harm remain despite taking available remedial action? An obligation to notify may be avoided if the organization takes remedial action promptly to prevent the risk of harm from occurring, either by making the harm unlikely to occur or by rendering it non-serious. If the answer to these questions is yes, then the breach classifies as an eligible (notifiable) data breach, and organizations are required to notify the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) and any affected individuals . It is essential to conduct an assessment of the suspected breach within 30 days of its occurrence to determine the likelihood of serious harm. If the risk of serious harm is likely, the organization has the same notification obligations as known data breaches under the Notifiable Data Breaches (NDB) scheme . Additionally, the Data Breach Response Plan outlines the steps for remedial action that can be taken at any point throughout the data breach response process and encourages documenting the process for further review and improvement .

To evaluate whether a known data breach is notifiable, consider the following three questions: • Has there been unauthorised access, unauthorised disclosure, accidental loss, or theft of personal information that the organisation holds? Data Breach Response Plan _POL_V01_2305 1|Page Data breach response plan For example, the organisation’s database is hacked, a portable storage device containing personal information is lost, or the organisation accidentally releases personal information to the wrong person. • Is it likely that this may result in serious harm to individual/s whose data has been breached? This can include but is not limited to psychological, financial, emotional, physical or reputational harm. To be able to accurately assess the likelihood and seriousness of harm, it requires looking at the context of the data and how it may have been breached. For information about the factors to consider when deciding whether harm is likely and/or serious, refer to section 26WG of the Privacy Amendment (Notifiable Data Breaches) Act 2017 • Does the likelihood of serious harm remain despite taking available remedial action? The obligation to notify the OAIC can be avoided if the organisation takes remedial action in a timely manner to prevent the risk of harm occurring, either by making the harm unlikely to occur, or non-serious. If the answer to the above three questions is yes, then the breach classifies as an eligible data breach and organisations are required to notify the OAIC and any affected individuals. If there are reasonable grounds to suspect that there has been a data breach, the data response team should conduct an assessment of the suspected breach. The assessment of a suspected breach must take place within 30 days of it occurring, and should seek to find out the likelihood of serious harm occurring as a result of the suspected breach. If it is assessed to be likely, this has the same notification obligations as a known data breach under the NDB Scheme. Take remedial action Remedial action can be taken at any point throughout the data breach response process – the sooner the better. However, it may be that the full extent and nature of the breach, and therefore the actions that could be taken, are not known until after assessing and investigating the breach. Examples of remedial action include remotely deleting sensitive information from a laptop which has been lost, or emailing affected individuals with advice to change their password details for an online account for which login information may have been hacked. The data breach response team should document the process of any remedial action, making sure to document rationale and reasoning as to why a certain conclusion has been made. If, after the remedial action has been taken, the risk of harm is reduced so that it is unlikely to occur, or non-serious, then there is no requirement to notify. Even if there is no requirement, however, the data response team should consider whether to contact affected individuals with advice for further protecting their information as a customer service measure. Notify Once a breach has been assessed as eligible, relevant individuals and bodies should be notified as soon as practicable. Notification must include the following information as a minimum: Data Breach Response Plan _POL_V01_2305 2|Page Data breach response plan • The organisation’s name and contact details • Description of the data breach • Type of information involved in the breach • Advice and recommendations for individuals to take in response 1. The OAIC The CEO is responsible for notifying and liaising with the OAIC for data breaches which have been assessed as eligible for the purposes of the Notifiable Data Breaches Scheme, using the OAIC’s Notifiable Data Breach form. 2. Notification of individuals who are at likely risk of serious harm due to the data breach The way notification occurs will depend on the context and nature of the breach, and the relationship of the individuals affected to the organisation. It should occur as soon as practicable after completing the notification statement for the OAIC. Individuals may be contacted by phone and email. A public notification may also occur. Notification to affected individuals may contain an explanation of what happened to their personal information, an apology, description of what measures have been put in place as a result of the breach, and advice on what they can do to further protect their information. Record and review Data breach log A data breach log will record all instances of data breaches or suspected breaches, as well as document assessments of the breach and any changes made as a result of a breach. All staff should be made aware of the log, and the CEO will be responsible for ensuring that all breaches or suspected breaches are recorded accurately in the log. Review Whether or not the breach or suspected breach was notifiable, a review should be conducted into processes relating to the breach to strengthen protections in the future. Depending on the type and seriousness of the breach, this may include: • A full investigation into how the breach occurred • Implement measures to ensure it does not reoccur, documented in a prevention plan • Reviews of security, cybersecurity and ICT policies and procedures • Audit of implementation of relevant policies and procedures • Additional staff training about privacy and data breach responses Data Breach Response Plan _POL_V01_2305 3|Page
response: The standard timeline for responding to a data breach, as outlined in the Data Breach Response Plan [Data_Breach_Response_Plan_POL_V01_2305], is as follows: Immediate Action: As soon as a data breach or suspected breach is identified, immediate steps should be taken to contain or limit any potential harm. Preliminary Assessment: The CEO will make a preliminary assessment and, if necessary, begin immediate action to contain the breach. Detailed Assessment and Escalation: The incident will be escalated to the data breach response team if more investigation is needed to understand the nature and extent of the breach, and whether it is an ‘eligible’ (notifiable) breach. Conduct an Assessment within 30 Days: If there is reasonable grounds to suspect a breach, the team should conduct an assessment of the suspected breach within 30 days of it occurring to determine the likelihood of serious harm resulting from the breach. Notification: If a breach is assessed as eligible, relevant individuals and the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) should be notified as soon as practicable after completing the assessment. Record and Review: Document the data breach, including assessments and any changes made in response to the breach. Additionally, a review should be conducted into processes relating to the breach to strengthen protections for the future . By adhering to this timeline, the organization ensures a prompt and responsible reaction to data breaches, mitigating the associated risks and impacts.
